today on hot Thai kitchen we are making pork 
stock and as a bonus gang jeud Woon sen Sawaddee

ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen today we are 
going back to basics and looking at one of the

most important building blocks of Thai cuisine 
and that is pork stock now knowing how to make

pork stock is a very essential skill to have in 
the kitchen but on top of that I've got future

recipes coming up that are going to use pork 
stock so I'm just getting you all prepared for

it and then at the end as a bonus I'll throw in a 
quick soup recipe that you can use your stock for

right away but before we proceed why is a good 
stock so important having a good stock in your

dish will give a dish that richness in flavor 
that's really subtle and you can't quite put

your finger on but it can mean the difference 
between a dish that spreads alright and a dish

that wow that's really good and it's that junus 
a quad that really pops the flavors of your dish

now while chicken stock is very commonly used in 
Western cuisine in Tigers in pork stock is the

star so let's get started for the stuff you will 
need two pounds of pork bones four to five cloves

of garlic the top of one lemongrass - cilantro 
roots some white peppercorns and half an onion

so I've got here two pounds of pork bones sitting 
here this is neck bone but you can use bones from

any part of the pig but the more cartilage the 
bone has the more flavorful the stock becomes

you can get pork bones at most Asian butchers 
or the meat department of an Asian grocery store

they usually have them otherwise you can also 
ask the butcher because if they sell pork and

they butcher the pork the pig the bones have to 
go somewhere and it's usually very cheap so I've

rinsed it just to make sure it's clean going in 
and I'm going to add three and a half liters of

cold water and then I'm going to bring this to 
a simmer you can put it over high heat but you

don't want this vigorously boiling you just wanted 
to come to a simmer have some lazy bubbles going

around and then once it comes to a simmer you 
want to turn the heat to low obviously so it

doesn't keep boiling and then we're going to let 
it simmer just by itself for about an hour so you

might be wondering why are we boiling bones what 
is it in the bones that makes a stock taste so

good and so the main thing that we're going for 
is the collagen in the bones which exists more

in cartilage than in the heart bones but what 
happens when collagen gets heated is it gets

dissolved into the water and becomes gelatin 
and that's why when you have a really strong

stock you put it in the fridge and it comes out 
jiggling like jello and that gelatin gives sort

of a richer thicker mouthfeel and so you make 
soup out of it the soup will feel richer rather

than thin like water and on top of that you've 
also got all sorts of organic material that's

in the bones and in the marrow that just plain 
tastes good so that's why bones are so valuable

while our stock is simmering let's look at our 
aromatics now in a western-style stock you've got

the mirepoix the onion carrots and celery which 
you can use but since we're going to use this

pretty much exclusively for Thai food I'm going to 
do it Asian style so first what I've got is what

I'm going to use is the top of a lemongrass now 
when I make when I cook with lemongrass like in

my tummy I'm going episode I tell you to cut it 
in half and then get rid of the top will I'll I

don't get rid of it save it for stock so here's 
a full lemongrass guy cut the bottom off I take

all this nasty bits and then I get the top and 
I'm going to save since this is such a dry sat

lemongrass I'm going to cut off more I'm going to 
save this part for cooking and in this part I'm

going to use for stock want to cut off this bit 
as well and it's perfect because the flavor here

is not very strong which is why you don't want to 
cook with it but it's perfect for style because

for a stock you don't want stock tasting like 
lemongrass but it's subtle enough that it adds

a little bit of bright citrus quality that that 
just brings up the flavor a notch so it's perfect

I'm just going to cut it into two pieces I really 
should have crushed that but do it after the fact

that's okay and then I've also got cilantro 
roots which I'm also going to smash oh this

is frozen and just thought so it's perfect it's 
already mushy cilantro roots if you cannot find

santa roots just used a bunch of stems use more 
though use like 6-7 stems so got that and then

I've also got garlic just four or five cloves with 
I which I've crushed so it helps really release

its magical ingredients out faster and then I've 
also got white peppercorns which I've crushed just

take some peppercorns and crush it with the side 
of your knife like this until they crack again to

help it release their flavors and then finally 
some onions which I've just cut up just to give

the stalk a nice natural sweetness a lot of Thai 
people also like to put daikon which works well I

prefer the flavor of onion to daikon so that's 
why I like to use onion but you're more than

welcome to do daikon if you want so we're going 
to get this all ready and add it to our stock so

our stock has been simmering now for I think 45 
minutes I rushed it a little bit just want you

to notice the speed at which it is bubbling it's 
it's got bubbles coming up but it's slow it's not

vigorously boiling the reason why you don't want 
it vigorously boiling see all the scum that has

come up that's what we're going to get rid of and 
if it's boiling all the scum keeps getting stirred

back into the stock and the stock just gets cloudy 
now this is just a bunch of fat and protein that

has floated to the top it's completely edible 
there's nothing wrong with it but it just doesn't

look very good so so that's the really the only 
reason why people remove it and after simmering

for about an hour most of the scum should have 
come up already and these little white bits that's

floating around that's just marrow taste really 
good we're going to go in with all our aromatics

garlic oh and one of the reason why we don't 
want to add all these from right from the

beginning is because look at them all if this 
was floating you're skimming of the scum will

be very difficult because then it'll get tangled 
up in all these vegetables and and then from this

point on you want to keep it going for about 45 
minutes to an hour pork stock you want a total

of about two hours of simmering the smaller the 
bones the less time you need so you your bones

are cut smaller you might not need as long for 
chicken stock because the bones are smaller and

thinner an hour to an hour and a half we'll 
do beef stock they generally do it for three

hours so it's all about how big the bones are 
so we're gonna let that go so it's done so now

we just have to turn it off and then remove 
the bones you could just pour it down a bit

colander but I don't have a big colander here 
depending on which bone you have you might have

a lot of meat left on it which is the case for 
this neck bone and so don't waste that pick it

out it should be super fork-tender right now then 
toss it into a soup or stir fry super super yummy

and now to store this you just have to put it 
in freezer ziplock bags like these this size

is good if you put it in a bigger one then it 
becomes really really hard to thaw because you

know it's huge so if you keep them here it'll be 
and especially if you keep it thin you can even if

you don't need a lot you can even snap it in half 
and then only thaw out what you need and then if

you keep it sealed really really well you can dip 
this in hot water and it'll come out more easily

and thought faster so perfect way to store the 
stock and now I promised you that I was going to

show you how you can quickly turn this stock into 
a soup and what that soup is it's called gang-du

twin scent and it's like the ultimate home comfort 
food it's it's a soup that every home makes is so

fast and easy and all the ingredients are very 
basic so let's go make that soup so I'm going

to first fry some garlic on low heat what we want 
is the golden brown crispy garlic and then bring

it up with cold oil slowly until it's all golden 
and crispy and this will be essentially garlic oil

that we're going to use to flavor our soup very 
also staple basic ingredient in a lot of Thai

cooking okay so now we're getting really close you 
want to pay attention this is like frying shallots

that I did in Pattaya Fried Chicken episode it 
goes from almost burnt almost cooked to burnt

very quickly so when it's kind of almost done I 
remove it it'll continue to cook a little bit now

this stuff is now really aromatic and garlicky 
and you can use it to flavor different things

garnish different things a little bit of oil left 
in there is okay we're gonna use that as a part of

our soup so we've got here some pork stock I'm 
not giving you any instruction I mean amounts

because this is really straightforward and you 
really don't need any got our freshly made stock

going in there I've got some ground pork that I'm 
going to season a little bit with some soy sauce

just a little bit so it's got some flavor white 
pepper I'm just going to mix it up it's starting

to bubble a little bit I'm going to add my pork 
chunks okay you're going to let that cook into the

exterior looks done I forgot to season the stock 
because the stock is unsalted and you always want

the stock to be unsalted so you can control the 
salt a little bit of soy sauce a little bit of

fish sauce just a splash little white pepper in 
the soup itself some people like to add a little

bit of sugar but our stock is already a little 
sweet from the onion so I'm going to skip that

hmm a little salt I add a little salt because I 
don't want the soup to look Brown from all the

soy sauce I give it okay so the pork is sort of 
halfway done now I'm going to go in with my napa

cabbage which are leafy things like this that we 
use often in soups and things let that settle this

is great kids food too by the way because it's not 
spicy at all really easy to eat and the vegetable

is mild flavor so it's a great way to get kids 
to eat veggies I love this as a kid okay the

vegetables are kind of settling down we're going 
to add our glass noodles or we sang which I have

soaked in cold water for about 15 minutes ten to 
fifteen minutes until it's softened and I also cut

it didn't cut it very well there was one long 
one there and then I just let it cook and now

all I'm going to do is bring this to a boil and 
then when it reaches a boil it should be done

so let's finish this off with some garnish so 
remember our fried garlic I'm just gonna drain

off the excess oil and it's now nice and crispy 
I'm just gonna top it off and then if you want

extra garlic enos you just sprinkle a little bit 
of the garlic oil around this is obvious good on

a lot of things so you might want to make some 
extra and keep some around for other purposes

some green onion and cilantro just to finish off 
as much as you'd like ooh that looks nice a little

extra white pepper if you want it a little spicier 
come on there mmm and that's it this is skank dude

wouldn't send made from our wonderful pork stock 
it is kind of like the chicken noodle soup of Thai

cuisine such comfort food and its really great if 
you're making something spicy to make this on the

side just wash this down that's spice real real 
nice so I hope you get a chance to make some pork

stock and when you do make sure you save some 
extra because I will promise that they'll be

recipes that will put your wonderful wonderful
